fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Assistant Professor at the University at Buffalo.

I am joining GÃ¶teborgs universitet ðŸ‡¸ðŸ‡ª in the autumn of 2024. Before that, I was a student mentored by Andrew Hirsch at the University at Buffalo ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸, where I earned my Master's degree in computer science. I am mainly interested in category theory and topos theory and their application in logic. Currently, I am mentored by Ivan Di Liberti. I come from an East Asian country called Taiwan ðŸ‡¹ðŸ‡¼.

This website is created using Jon Sterling's Forester tool. The purpose of this website is to maintain my personal notes. I often find myself rewriting the same things across several notebooks because it is faster than finding and referencing the relevant notes. Forester allows me to easily link related notes.

If you find any error, no matter how trivial, please contact me through my email: frankdec24 (at) gmail (dot) com. Any comments, reading suggestions, and advice are greatly appreciated. To help me integrate into Swedish society, I plan to maintain a list of articles on Swedish etiquette, culture, and language here in the near future.
To navigate this forest, press Ctrl + K.
A category \mathcal { C } is locally cartesian iff it has pullbacks.

If \mathcal { C } is locally cartesian, then { \mathcal { C } _{/ A }} has products for any object A \in \mathcal { C }. But, products in { \mathcal { C } _{/ A }} are pullbacks over A. Thus, \mathcal { C } has pullbacks.

Conversely, assume that \mathcal { C } has pullbacks. Then since the forgetful functor \Sigma _{A} \colon { \mathcal { C } _{/ A }} \to \mathcal { C } creates connected limits for any object A \in \mathcal { C }, the slice { \mathcal { C } _{/ A }} has pullbacks. Moreover, \mathsf {id} _{ A } is the terminal object in { \mathcal { C } _{/ A }}. Thus, { \mathcal { C } _{/ A }} is cartesian.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Slice comparison functor of a locally cartesian category admits a right adjoint

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A category \mathcal { C } is locally cartesian iff for all morphisms f of \mathcal { C }, the functor \Sigma _{f} constructed in admits a right adjoint f ^{*}.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Categories with a subobject classifier are cartesian

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If \mathcal { C } is a category with pullbacks equipped with a subobject classifier then \mathcal { C } is cartesian.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By , \mathcal { C } has a terminal object. Thus, it follows that \mathcal { C } has all finite limits.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Domain of the generic subobject is terminal

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \top \colon \Omega ' \to \Omega be the generic subobject of a category \mathcal { C } with pullbacks, then \Omega ' is terminal.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Isomorphic subobjects have the same classifying morphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let m \colon A' \rightarrowtail A and n \colon A'' \rightarrowtail A be subobjects. Then m \cong n in \mathsf { Sub } (A) iff \chi _{m} = \chi _{n}.
A category \mathcal { C } is said to be locally cartesian if for any object A \in \mathcal { C }, the slice { \mathcal { C } _{/ A }} is cartesian.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monomorphisms in a category equipped with a subobject classifier are regular

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal { C } be a cartesian category equipped with a subobject classifier. Every monomorphism in \mathcal { C } is regular.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
Note that the generic subobject \top \colon 1 \rightarrowtail \Omega is a split monomorphism, so it is also a regular monomorphism. Explicitly, \top is the equalizer of \mathsf {id} _{ \Omega } and \Omega \xrightarrow { \mathsf {!} _{ \Omega } } 1 \xrightarrow { \top } \Omega.
Since every monomorphism in \mathcal { C } is a pullback against \top and regular monomorphisms are stable under pullback, it follows that every monomorphism in \mathcal { C } is regular.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal { C } be an arbitrary category and f \colon A \to B be a morphism. There is a faithful functor \Sigma _{f} \colon { \mathcal { C } _{/ A }} \to { \mathcal { C } _{/ B }} whose action on objects is the assignment g \mapsto fg.
Note that the category { ( { \mathcal { C } _{/ B }} ) _{/ f }} consists of the following data:
Thus, we may take \Sigma _{f} to be the forgetful functor { ( { \mathcal { C } _{/ B }} ) _{/ f }} \to { \mathcal { C } _{/ A }}.
If \mathcal { C } has pullbacks then the assignment A \mapsto \mathsf { Sub } (A) can be extended to a pseudofunctor \mathsf { Sub } \colon \mathcal { C } ^ \mathrm {op} \to \mathsf { CAT }.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
It suffices to specify an action on morphisms. Let f \colon A \to B be an arbitrary morphism. Since monomorphisms are stable under pullback, the pullback functor f ^{*} \colon { \mathcal { C } _{/ B }} \to { \mathcal { C } _{/ A }} restricts to a functor f ^{*} \colon \mathsf { Sub } (B) \to \mathsf { Sub } (A). Then pseudofunctoriality follows from the following facts:
Let f \colon A \to B, g \colon B \to C, and m \colon C' \rightarrowtail C be given. By the pasting lemma of pullbacks, the pullback f ^{*} g ^{*} (m) is also a pullback along gf. Thus, the universal property of pullbacks guarantees that (gf) ^{*} (m) \cong f ^{*} g ^{*} (m) in \mathsf { Sub } (A).
The pullback against the identity is always an isomorphism. Thus, for any m \colon A' \rightarrowtail A, \mathsf {id} _{ A } ^{*} (m) \cong m in \mathsf { Sub } (A).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal { C } be a category with pullbacks. The subobject classifier of \mathcal { C } is the terminal object (if it exists) of the category \mathcal { S } _{ \mathcal { C } } defined by the following data:

html:tr.html:td: An object of \mathcal { S } _{ \mathcal { C } } is a pair (A, m), where A is an object in \mathcal { C } and m \colon A' \rightarrowtail A is a subobject.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Identities and compositions of \mathcal { S } _{ \mathcal { C } } are inherited from \mathcal { C }.
Let A be any object in a topos and let \{ \} \colon A \to \Omega ^{A} be the name of the diagonal relation \Delta \colon A \rightarrowtail A \times A. \{ \} is a monomorphism.

Let B be an object in a category \mathcal { C }. A subobject of B is a monomorphism m \colon A \rightarrowtail B. The category of subobjects of B, denoted as \mathsf { Sub } (B), is the full subcategory of { \mathcal { C } _{/ B }} spanned by monomorphisms.
Every topos is balanced.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By , every monomorphism is regular. Thus, any epic monomorphism is automatically an isomorphism.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Separated objects correspond to closed diagonal relations

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An object A of a topos \mathcal { E } is separated iff the diagonal subobject \Delta \colon A \rightarrowtail A \times A is closed.
A (Lawvere-Tierney) topology on a topos \mathcal { E } is a morphism j \colon \Omega \to \Omega satisfying the following equations.
Let j be a topology on a topos. A subobject m \colon A \rightarrowtail B is said to be j-closed if its closure is isomorphic to itself.
Let j be a topology on a topos. Let m \colon A \rightarrowtail B be a subobject. The j-closure of m is the subobject classified by j \chi _{m} \colon B \to \Omega.
Let j be a topology on a topos. A subobject m \colon A \rightarrowtail B is said to be j-dense if its closure is an isomorphism.
An equivalence relation is said to be effective if it is the kernel pair of some morphism.
Let (a,b) \colon R \rightarrowtail A \times A be a relation in a category with finite limits. (a,b) is said to be an equivalence relation if it is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Every equivalence relation in a topos is effective

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (a,b) \colon R \rightarrowtail A \times A be a relation in a category with finite limits. (a,b) is said to be reflexive if the diagonal relation \Delta \colon A \rightarrowtail A \times A factors through (a,b), i.e., there is a map \rho \colon A \to R such that a \rho = b \rho = \mathsf {id} _{ A }.

Let j be a topology on a topos \mathcal { E }. An object S \in \mathcal { E } is said to be j-separated if for any dense subobject m \colon A \rightarrowtail B and any morphism f \colon A \to S, there is at most one morphism g \colon B \to S such that f = gm.

Let j be a topology on a topos \mathcal { E }. An object S \in \mathcal { E } is said to be a j-sheaf if for any dense subobject m \colon A \rightarrowtail B and any morphism f \colon A \to S, there is exactly one morphism g \colon B \to S such that f = gm.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Subobjects of separated objects are separated

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let A be a separated object in a topos \mathcal { E }. Any subobject m \colon A' \rightarrowtail A is separated.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Let m' \colon B' \rightarrowtail B be a dense subobject and f \colon B' \to A' be any morphism. If f = gm' = hm' then mf = mgm' = mhm'. First, mg = mh because A is separated. Then it follows that g = h because m is a monomorphism.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (a,b) \colon R \rightarrowtail A \times A be a relation in a category with finite limits. (a,b) is said to be symmetric if the twisted relation (b,a) factors through (a,b), i.e., there is a map \sigma \colon R \to R such that a \sigma = b and b \sigma = a.

Let (a,b) \colon R \rightarrowtail A \times A be a relation in a category with finite limits. (a,b) is said to be transitive if the relation (ap,bq) \colon R \times _{A} R \rightarrowtail A \times A factors through (a,b), i.e., there is a map \tau \colon R \times _{A} R \to R such that a \tau = ap and b \tau = bq, where p and q are the projection maps of the following pullback.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = R \times _{A} R, ne = R, sw = R, se = A, nw/style = pullback, north = q, west = p, south = b, east = a, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An (elementary) topos is a finitely complete and cartesian closed category equipped with a subobject classifier.
A geometric morphism f \colon \mathcal { E } \to \mathcal { F } is said to be essential if its inverse image f ^{*} admits a left adjoint.
Let \mathcal { E } and \mathcal { F } be topoi. A geometric morphism f \colon \mathcal { E } \to \mathcal { F } is an adjoint pair of functors
such that f ^{*} is left exact. The functors f _{*} and f ^{*} are called the direct image and the inverse image respectively.

Let f , g \colon \mathcal { E } \rightrightarrows \mathcal { F } be a pair of geometric morphisms. A geometric transformation \alpha \colon f \to g is a natural transformation \alpha \colon f _{*} \to g _{*}.
Let \mathcal { E } and \mathcal { F } be topoi. A logical functor F \colon \mathcal { E } \to \mathcal { F } is a functor preserving finite limits, exponentials, and the subobject classifier.
A monoidal category consists of the following data.

fr:ul.fr:li: A functor \otimes \colon \mathcal { C } \times \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { C } called the monoidal product.
An object 1 \in \mathcal { C } called the monoidal unit.
A natural isomorphism \alpha _{{ X },{ Y },{ Z }} \colon (X \otimes Y) \otimes Z \to X \otimes (Y \otimes Z) called the associator.
A natural isomorphism \lambda _{ X } \colon 1 \otimes X \to X called the left unitor.
A natural isomorphism \rho _{ X } \colon X \otimes 1 \to X called the right unitor.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These data are subject to the following axioms.
The following diagram commutes.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = (X \otimes 1 ) \otimes Y, sw = X \otimes Y, se = X \otimes Y, ne = X \otimes ( 1 \otimes Y), east = X \otimes \lambda _{ Y } , west = \rho _{ X } \otimes Y, north = \alpha _{{ X },{ 1 },{ Y }} , south/style = {double}, height = 1.5cm, width = 3.5cm, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Moreover the equality \lambda _{ 1 } = \rho _{ 1 } \colon 1 \otimes 1 \to 1 holds.
The following diagram commutes.
Let \mathcal { C } and \mathcal { D } be monoidal categories. A monoidal functor F \colon \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { D } consists of the following data.

fr:ul.fr:li: An underlying functor F \colon \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { D }.
A natural transformation \phi ^{2} _{ X , Y } \colon FX \otimes FY \to F(X \otimes Y).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: These data are subject to the following axioms.
The following diagram commutes.
The following diagram commutes.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = 1 _{ \mathcal { D } } \otimes FX, sw = F 1 _{ \mathcal { C } } \otimes FX, se = F( 1 _{ \mathcal { C } } \otimes X), ne = FX, east = F \lambda _{ \mathcal { C } }, west = \phi ^{1} \otimes FX, north = \lambda _{ \mathcal { D } }, south = \phi ^{2} _{ 1 _{ \mathcal { C } } , X } , height = 2cm, width = 3cm, }

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The following diagram commutes.

fr:embedded-tex.fr:embedded-tex-body: \DiagramSquare { nw = FX \otimes 1 _{ \mathcal { D } }, sw = FX \otimes F 1 _{ \mathcal { C } }, se = F(X \otimes 1 _{ \mathcal { C } }), ne = FX, east = F \rho _{ \mathcal { C } }, west = FX \otimes \phi ^{1} , north = \rho _{ \mathcal { D } }, south = \phi ^{2} _{ X , 1 _{ \mathcal { C } } } , height = 2cm, width = 3cm, }

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Monomorphisms are equalizers in a topos

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In a topos, every monomorphism is an equalizer.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is an immediate consequence of .

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A monoidal category is said to be strict if \alpha, \lambda, and \rho are all identities.
A monoidal functor is said to be strict if \phi ^{2} and \phi ^{1} are identities.
A monoidal functor is said to be strong if \phi ^{2} and \phi ^{1} are isomorphisms.
